data.title: Historic Attraction
data.text: I was pleased that Denton County chooses to honor its history and that symbols of that past history still stand on the courthouse lawn. The men and women on both sides of the Civil War fought for various reasons but one of those was defending their homeland.

data.title: One cannon ball is missing!
data.text: I'm glad the statute is still there considering the movement to shame all Confederate soldiers. It would be nice if the missing stone cannon ball would be replaced.

data.title: Smaller than I expected
data.text: I'm a history buff, so I enjoyed seeing it, but it was a tad disappointing. It was smaller than expected and the inscription could be better.

data.title: See It While You Can
data.text: With the plague of Political Correctness spreading like a virulent flu, monuments that dare to display the dreaded "C-word" (Confederate) are under attack.  The Denton Confederate Soldier Monument stands where it has since 1918 but has been vandalized more than once and you may see protesters with signs demanding it be removed.  But anyone that bothers to learn the actual history of the monument knows there is nothing racist about it.  See and learn about monuments like this while you can before they are removed because they don't fit a particular political narrative.

data.title: part of Denton, learn the history before you judge.
data.text:
Years ago, when I first got to Denton, I was a bit shocked about this, until I learned about the history behind it.

The majority of men who died fighting for the Confederate army out of Denton were conscribed, ergo, drafted.  They did not want to fight, but they did not want to have their homes overrun either.   Most of them served their time on the border, fighting the marauding indians who were coming down to kill the folks of Texas.

When you actually learn why it is there, how can you not appreciate it.

data.title: Heritage Not Hate
data.text:
The Confederate Memorial is well worth spending few minutes with while you are strolling around the square and the Courthouse on the Square. From time to time there are always seem to be the unfortunate few who feel that they must damage and protest the existence of this wonderful tribute to the history of Denton County. Accept is for what it is. A tribute to the fallen soldiers who gave their lives to a cause in which they believed. 
Highly Recommended.

data.title: Remembering the Past.
data.text: This memorial has been here long before attending the university back in 1965.  It is a part of history and is worth seeing. Some  want to change it at the expense of others who would like it to remain.

data.title: It is History
data.text: Sure, times have changed, but those that forget history are likely to repeat it.  Besides, this is not in support of racism, slavery, etc...but a memorial to soldiers.  The Civil War, although a terrible time in our history, should not be forgotten nor should the core reasons it took place, many of which had nothing to do with the horrible practice of slavery.

data.title: not politically corresc
data.text: I like this memorial.  I know that it is not politically correct and some people want it removed, but it is part of the local history.  There is a disclaimer notice, which should be enough.

data.title: Not much to it
data.text: All the controversy aside, there's just not much to this monument worth seeing. If you are on the square anyway, take a look, but certainly don't come because of it.

data.title: Gotta go
data.text: Time for it to get gone - Denton, you can do better! Our world has changed, we need to change too. I know it's there to memorialize fallen soldiers, and you put up a make-nice marker there, but it gots to go!

data.title: Confederate States of America
data.text: Wonderful memorial that is important to Texas history.  It is a nice reminder of the effort that Texas and other states fought for their independence.

data.title: Historical Memorial
data.text: This is located on the Denton square in front of the magnificent old courthouse building. It is a very beautiful and respectful tribute to those who gave their lives in the Civil War.

data.title: Worth a stop.
data.text: Much to do in a 10 minute walking distance around the Denton square. After a meal and a stop for ice cream,  check out this simple but dignified memorial. Then go across the street to the bookstore for a long visit in the history shelves.
